head.title: Confidence Intervals for the Population Mean

body.p: The purpose of this activity is to learn how to use statistical software for calculating confidence intervals for μ (when σ is known). Software is particularly useful when all you have are the raw data (no summary has been calculated), which is what you encounter in practice. In all the examples and activities we looked at so far, the sample mean is given (rather than the whole data set), in which case it will often take you less time to calculate the confidence interval by hand than to launch a software program and ask it to do the calculation for you.

Background: Some studies suggest that women having their first baby at age 35 or older are at increased risk of having a baby with a low birth weight. A medical researcher wanted to estimate μ, the mean weight of newborns who are the first child for women over the age of 35. To this end, the researcher chose a random sample of 125 women ages 35 and older who were pregnant with their first child and followed them through the pregnancy. The datafile linked below contains the birth weight (in grams) of the 125 newborns (women pregnant with more than one child were excluded from the study). From past research, it is assumed that the weight of newborns has a standard deviation of σ = 500 grams. We will estimate μ with a 99% confidence interval.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the data set preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame birthweight. Enter the command birthweight to see the data. The variable name in the data frame is also birthweight.
In R, there is no specific command to calculate a z-based confidence interval. We will use other functions in R to calculate the components of the confidence interval.
First, we will reassign the variable of interest to the variable name x.
Now we will calculate the necessary sample statistics, such as the sample mean, x̄, the sample size, n, and the z critical value:

ol.li:
Set your Confidence Level, C, and z critical value, z:
C=0.99
z=qnorm((1+C)/2)

Set your Population Standard Deviation, sigma:
sigma=500

Calculate the sample mean, xbar, and sample size, n:
n=length(x)
xbar=mean(x)

alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: A dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."

Make sure the "samples in columns" option is selected, and enter the variable's name under it (or simply double-click on it in the panel on the left).
Next to "Standard deviation," enter the value of σ.
To choose the level of confidence, click on Options and select it.
Click "OK" twice.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
To create a confidence interval, we need to calculate two values: the sample mean (which is our best estimate for the population mean), and the margin of error. Excel can do both of these for us:

ul.li: To calculate the sample mean, simply take the average of all of the values of the dataset: =average(A2:A126).

To calculate the margin of error, we can use an Excel function called CONFIDENCE.NORM(a,s,n), where a is the alpha value, s is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size. Note that the alpha value a = 1 - C, where C is the confidence level (in our case, 0.99). In this case, we enter the formula as follows: =CONFIDENCE.NORM(0.01, 500, 125), which gives us 115.19 for our margin of error.
The confidence interval is then written as (estimate - margin of error, estimate + margin of error). For this example we would write (2996.19, 3226.55) as the confidence interval.
